> ARGH! This violently breaks the beautiful encapsulation property that helps 
> define OO programming. If you want to know whether an object is valid, send 
> it the message "isValid()".


not if you need to test a class and you don't have access to the code... 
  Anyway, you can always find exemples where a test methodology doesn't 
fit well...

We can argue endlessly if you can/can't have access to a private 
method/field.  It's almost a religious crusade :-)  I personally prefer 
to let people choose if they want to use a feature or not: integrate the 
feature, present the pros and cons and let the user decide.  He's 
certainly old enough to know what he's doing.

I'm quite sure you don't test your protected methods, even if this 
feature is available with JUnit.  And you won't test your private 
methods event if this feature is also available.  You can certainly 
resist the temptation :-)
